subject: Re: [junit] J2EE "patterns"
msgSnippet: It wasn t my intent to reason If the language does not support it, then it is a hack. It was my intent to reason If an implementation pattern exists to
messageBody:
It wasn't my intent to reason "If the language does not support it, then it is a hack." It was my intent to reason "If an implementation 'pattern' exists to combat a weakness in the design of a framework, then it is a hack."

But that's quite interesting -- the link you provided.

Take care.

So said Bill de hÓra on 4/5/2003 --------------------
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

[[[
I do not react well to calling J2EE implementation idioms "patterns".
They are hacks designed to increase performance and work around the
obvious limitations and faulty intentions of J2EE.
]]]

You can take this reasoning quite a-ways:

http://norvig.com/design-patterns/img010.gif

to the point where if you're not using Lisp or something very like
it, most patterns are hacks.

In the meantime... ;)

Bill de hÓra
